text:
Recently, there have been questions regarding the district's curriculum and standards. We would like to reassure everyone that our district has an open-door to any and all curriculum and instruction related questions. Our building principals and central office leaders are always willing to meet and review our curriculum and instructional material. We welcome the input of our community and value your feedback. Please know that our teaching teams work tirelessly to develop high quality learning experiences for all of our students. With this in mind, we would also like to share the following:

1. All of our curriculum is based on the Missouri Learning Standards provided by the Department of Education (DESE).
2. Neither the Missouri Learning Standards or our curriculum address Critical Race Theory (CRT) or the 1619 Project.

Additionally, we have also had questions about the district's Leader in Me program. Leader in Me is based on the book, The 7 Habits of Highly Effective People. This program works to promote leadership and life skills in our students and was started here in 2016. The district researched this program extensively prior to implementation and believes strongly in developing the character and academic skills of all of our students. There is no evidence of CRT in the program. Character education has long been a priority of the Marshfield School District.

text:
Union Public Schools adopts diversity, equity and inclusion policy

Citing increasing diversity among the student body, Union Public Schools’ Board of Education unanimously adopted a new district-wide diversity, equity and inclusion policy Monday night.

As approved, the new policy states that the district appreciates diversity of thought, values, perspectives and personhood and is “committed to procedures intended to support a diverse and equitable school community in an inclusive manner.”

While presenting it to the school board Monday night, Superintendent Kirt Hartzler said the new policy is not an attempt to subvert state laws or introduce critical race theory into the classroom but is instead an affirmation of the district’s core values.

“I don’t know why we wouldn’t want to consider this,” he said, noting that more than 60 languages are spoken by Union students.

Continue: https://tulsaworld.com/news/local/education/union-public-schools-adopts-diversity-equity-and-inclusion-policy/article_09cd47a2-5c31-11ec-99cd-77a6acf22eca.html

text:
#Repost @risestrategygroup
・・・
"The First Amendment is America, and so is the Trail of Tears — which forcibly displaced the Indigenous People from their land in the name of expansion. The Civil Rights Act of 1964 is America, and so is the Three-Fifths Compromise — which counted each formerly enslaved individual as less than a whole person."

Founder and Head of School of Purpose Preparatory Academy (@purpose_prep) Lagra Newman (@lagra.newman) discusses the need to uplift questions of race and privilege in the classroom now, more than ever.

As bills aiming to ban critical race theory from classrooms are dominating national conversations about education, leaders like Lagra are stepping up and causing "good trouble" fighting back. Read more in the @tennessean. #linkinbio #goodtrouble #congressmanjohnlewis #criticalracetheory #derrickbell #kimberlecrenshaw #history #teachthetruth #educationisfreedom #knowledgeispower #education #purposeprep

text:
During this American Education Week, schools are facing so many challenges. How can we support them?

Here are a few suggestions:

Celebrate students by attending a play, concert, sporting event, or student activity.

Mentor a student or share your career path, professional expertise, or cultural traditions with a class.

Volunteer with a local organization supporting children and youth at www.unitedwaydgco.org.

Reinforce at home with your children positive behavior expectations, including safety, health and wellness, self-regulation, respect, responsibility, kindness, cooperation, empathy.

Participate in a parent organization, booster club, or school advisory committee.

Donate classroom supplies, warm clothing, socks and underwear, and hygiene items to schools.

Refer a friend or consider substitute teaching, driving a bus, or applying for a job in our schools at mhedteach.com, workatfirst.com, and www.usd497.org/Apply.

Stay informed by reading teacher communications and school newsletters, following our official accounts on social media, or watching a school board meeting.

Critically evaluate information about schools and seek the facts. (No, we don’t teach Critical Race Theory. Yes, culturally relevant teaching is a best practice.)

Advocate for your school - The legislative session starts in January! (See www.usd497.org/Educate Lawrence.)

T.H.I.N.K. before you post or share information about schools: Is it True? Helpful? Inspiring? Necessary? Kind?

Send thank-you notes to bus drivers, teachers, paras, secretaries, food service and custodial personnel, nurses, technology staff, librarians, administrators, school board members, and other professionals supporting students.

Nominate school staff for recognition at www.usd497.org/Recognition.

Support the Lawrence Schools Foundation at www.lawrenceschoolsfoundation.org.

Contact your child’s school for more ideas!

text:
SMSD Mr. Estep Letter to the SMSD Community
November 8, 2021

Dear SMSD Community,

On September 13, I stepped into the role of serving as SMSD’s Superintendent of Schools. I’m very happy to be here and believe my extensive leadership experience, which stretches back nearly 28 years, will be of real assistance in tackling some of the district’s systems issues which require immediate attention.

I have spent the better portion of my first seven weeks trying to fill key leadership positions which were vacated this past spring and summer. Bit by bit, a new leadership team has been onboarding over the last month and our team is now fully intact. This was the first priority to tackle upon my entry, and I’m very pleased with the quality of candidates we have managed to bring into our learning community.

During my short time here, we have found some specific operational systems utilized in business, payroll and human resources in recent years have either been inadequate, lacking appropriate checks and balances, or simply not following best practices for a nearly $40 million organization. To this end, I have spent a great deal of time digging deeper into how and why these systems were either not set up and administered properly, or fixing mistakes generated by a lack of a strategic approach to operations. This is all fixable, but it requires an initial investment of time, during which our new leadership team will thoroughly review files and systems, address and correct errors, and establish clear, redundant protocols and feedback loops for payroll, business and HR operations to run smoothly moving forward.

Since my arrival, I have met with various staff members, become acquainted with the people with whom I’m working and have gotten to know the board. Because we have needed to onboard so many new people, I’m also spending time either directly mentoring individuals or reaching out to experienced individuals in neighboring districts or school support organizations to assist in advising some of our new hires. At recent board meetings, I’ve referred to this as triage work and I’ve advised the board that most of my first nine to 10 months on the job will center on this. I have also been asked to recruit someone into the district whom I can mentor to replace me at the end of the 2022-2023 school year, as I prepare to retire.

I know some community members are concerned about whether the district intends to revisit the diversity and equity initiative which began last school year. Concerns were raised at a recent board meeting that the district had spent some $500,000 on diversity and equity curriculum and resources. Let me be clear: that DID NOT happen. Someone must have either been confused about a budget discussion on overall K-12 curriculum and professional development and textbook purchasing, or had their own agenda and spread false information. The bottom line is that SMSD has not expended $500,000 on diversity and equity initiatives. Regarding my stance on the formal JEDI initiative that began last school year, and was apparently tabled in the spring or early summer prior to my arrival, I ask that everyone refers to the priorities I’ve discussed in the first three paragraphs of this letter. In the immediate future, my focus is on fixing fundamental operations, preparing to develop a budget for next fiscal year, helping the district find its next superintendent, and working with my new leadership team to prioritize areas in need of immediate correction and fix them. After that, we will develop and implement long-term practices to ensure those areas function properly, well into the future. These areas of priority will occupy almost all of my time and the time of my core leadership team for the remainder of this school year.

Finally, regarding curriculum content: public schools are governed by Chapter 4 of the PA School Code of 1949. Over the years, there have been periodic updates to Chapter 4, which outlines what must be included in district curricular content. I have been a superintendent for nearly 18 years, and at no time during that span do I recall any update to Chapter 4 requiring public schools to teach Critical Race Theory as part of our curriculum—though for many, many years, there have been historical references in our guidelines for including discussion and analysis of domestic unrest, and racial and ethnic tension. If CRT had been mandated, every superintendent and curriculum director in the state would have received formal notification of this change—that has not happened, nor is it ever likely to happen.

Unfortunately, social media, media punditry and rabid politics have enabled susceptible individuals to be duped into linking any attempt to address concepts like diversity, racial bigotry, marginalization, or inequitable treatment of sub-groups to the so-called culture wars and government indoctrination of children. Here is a link to Chapter 4 on the PA Department of Education website: http://www.pacodeandbulletin.gov/Display/pacode?file=/secure/pacode/data/022/chapter4/chap4toc.html&d=. SMSD is attempting to follow it, pure and simple. If you examine the documents affiliated with Chapter 4, you will see references to things like domestic unrest and racial and ethnic tensions. These concepts will continue to be discussed in public school classrooms, whether against the backdrop of the American Civil War or our very recent and ongoing period of civil unrest.

As superintendent, I have no plans to revisit the JEDI initiative during my tenure here. Curriculum work will continue with the mapping of content in K-12 social studies and 6-12 world languages. Professional development for teachers is focused on improving instructional strategies for mathematics and language arts. My hope is that this letter serves as an introduction to me, articulates my role in year one, and clarifies my stance on the diversity and equity matter. The work of finding ways to help children feel less marginalized and more supported on a daily basis in classrooms and buildings across the district was happening prior to my arrival, will continue while I’m here, and will continue when I’m gone.

I am honored to serve with all the professionals and support staff who make this place run each and every day, and I am grateful to serve the Bubbler community during this time of transition.

Very Truly Yours,

James Estep
Superintendent

PACODEANDBULLETIN.GOV
022

text:
School Board Member Mrs. Jan Hayes (pictured in the center) represented District 1 at the 2020-2021 Equity Committee Meeting held in Montgomery at Alabama Association of School Boards.

The purpose of the meeting was to discuss how the various school boards address equity issues and the challenges they face in order to provide equity to our students. Topics of discussion included how AASB could better get school boards involved in equity training and Critical Race Theory. Mrs. Hayes commented, "It was a very interesting meeting and I’d love to see our board take advantage of this new training when it is available in the near future."

text:
It has come to the School District’s attention that someone is falsely and shamelessly accusing the school district of engaging in social emotional learning as a vehicle for critical race theory. Do not buy into this RECKLESS NONSENSE. Teachers teach the Georgia Standards of Excellence and develop competencies that include critical thinking, creativity, communication, collaboration, and personal responsibility. We DO NOT teach critical race theory! District leadership will evaluate resources used to foster personal responsibility to ensure they are congruent to the values and norms of our community. Our goal is to provide an educational environment where every student feels valued, and no student is marginalized.

You can learn more at https://pike.k12.ga.us/extended-portrait-of-a-graduate/

PIKE.K12.GA.US
Extended Portrait of a Graduate - Pike County Schools

text:
A statement from the USD 464 Superintendent:
Parents and Patrons of USD 464, there are many 2022 legislative issues being discussed and school districts across Kansas are receiving questions about “critical race theory” being taught in Kansas public schools. I can assure you that critical race theory is not taught in Kansas public schools or in Tonganoxie Schools. The Kansas State Board of Education sets the standards of the knowledge and skills that high school graduates should possess. Local school districts then develop their curriculum that identifies the specific ways to achieve those goals. For further information on KSDE Curriculum, I would refer you to the Social Studies Standards on the KSDE website at www.ksde.org. In addition, the attached document explains Critical Race Theory and the Kansas Standards and curriculum process in detail. Please feel free to contact me at the USD 464 District Office by calling 913-416-1400 if you have any additional questions.
Thank you,
Loren Feldkamp
Superintendent

text:
Clarification of Board Members' Position on Critical Race Theory

A recent news article seemingly indicated that four of our current Board of Education members, Cyndee Bratz, Amanda Karpus, John Schweitzer, and Steve Vaughn, support the teaching of Critical Race Theory (CRT) in our schools. This notion is not at all accurate. We have clearly and succinctly addressed CRT on multiple occasions at our Board meetings: we do not teach, nor do we have any plans to teach CRT in our schools. Our curricula are publicly adopted documents that are accessible through a public records request. Further, our course registration guide is available at https://www.parmacityschools.org/Page/1330. None of these contain any reference to CRT. It simply is not, nor will be, present in the Parma City School District.

Charlie

The basic tenets of critical race theory, or CRT, emerged out of a framework for legal analysis in the late 1970s and early 1980s
created by legal scholars Derrick Bell, Kimberlé Crenshaw, and Richard Delgado, among others."

text:
Interest in school board seats has surged, with conservative groups encouraging challenges by right-learning newcomers amid debates over COVID-19 mask mandates, gender-neutral bathrooms and teachings on race.

KCRG.COM
Opponents of critical race theory seek to flip school boards

text:
School board elections are being watched closely across the country as hot topics such as COVID-19, Critical Race Theory, and standardized testing is at the forefront of voters’ minds.

KCRG.COM
Center Point Urbana school board candidates speak at forum Sunday
post_text: School board elections are being watched closely across the country as hot topics such as COVID-19, Critical Race Theory, and standardized testing is at the forefront of voters’ minds.
shared_text:
KCRG.COM
Center Point Urbana school board candidates speak at forum Sunday

text:
It’s hard to believe that it’s already eight weeks into the school year. While we hoped that this year would allow for a return to normal, that has unfortunately not been the case. The pandemic continues to challenge school districts with positive cases, contract tracing, and quarantine protocols. Schools around the country are also coping with a sharp increase in mental health concerns as well as teacher and staffing shortages.

As the school year progresses, it has become clear that many students are struggling nationwide. The crisis in mental health has been growing for years, but the pandemic has accelerated it. Students are facing a number of challenges that are affecting their mental health, including feelings of isolation and anxiety, substance and alcohol use, and the unexpected deaths of loved ones from COVID-19. In response to this, our district has not only expanded our partnership with River Valley Counseling Center, but we have also added eight School Adjustment Counselor positions across our schools to help meet the needs of our students. We know that if our students are not in a healthy mental state, that they cannot adequately access our curriculum, which directly affects student achievement.

The COVID pandemic has triggered a spike in teacher retirements and resignations. In addition to teacher vacancies, schools around the country are facing food supply shortages, and struggle to find enough bus drivers, paraprofessionals, custodians and cafeteria workers. Many districts also face shortages of substitute teachers, who are needed now more than ever to cover for teachers who are out sick or quarantined. Some schools have closed when too many positions could not be filled, while others grapple with higher than normal unfilled positions, leaving remaining staff overworked.

The lack of qualified teachers in the US has worsened during the pandemic. Difficulties filling teacher openings continue to affect schools across the country. In South Dakota, one district started the school year with 120 teacher vacancies. In Texas, districts in Houston, Waco and other neighborhoods reported teacher vacancies in the hundreds as the school year began. Florida is short over 5000 teachers across the state. Our district still has over a dozen critical positions to fill and it’s already the middle of October.

The teacher shortage didn't start with COVID-19. Educators have been leaving the profession for years for a variety of reasons, and the pandemic only exacerbated the situation. According to a June survey of 2,690 members of the National Education Association, 32% said the pandemic was likely to make them leave the profession earlier than expected. Over the last 18 months, teacher workloads have increased considerably along with stress levels. In May, a survey by the CDC Foundation reported that 27% of teachers reported depression and 37% reported anxiety. Further complicating the staff shortages is the fact that fewer students are majoring in education at college and universities.

With election season upon us, it is my hope that candidates running for public office realize the actual issues facing our school system. As a community, we need to collaborate to solve the ongoing mental health crisis and lack of qualified school staffing. Schools nationwide have had to shut down classrooms because there just aren’t enough teachers. While this has not happened in Westfield yet, that day may come. Critics focusing on standardized test scores and outdated accountability data during a global pandemic is not helpful. Debating about masks or the myth that Critical Race Theory is being taught in our schools is equally nonproductive. If we truly hope to work together to create an environment where children can learn and thrive and be surrounded by positive role models and examples in their community, we need to acknowledge that our world is hurting, traumatized, and in need of healing. We also need to celebrate the good work that our educators, administrators, support staff and families do every day caring for our children.

But as you can imagine, RVC is also struggling to find qualified staff. Thank you for your patience.', 'comment_time': datetime.datetime(2021, 10, 24, 9, 35, 56), 'comment_image': 'https://scontent.xx.fbcdn.net/m1/v/t6/An_UvxJXg9tdnLU3Y5qjPi0200MLilhzPXUgxzGjQzUMaNcmjdZA6anyrngvkdub33NZzZhd51fpCAEzNHFhko5aKRFP5fS1w_lKwYrzcNLupv27.png?ccb=10-5&oh=00_AT_KPW4BOqeotp1qkXm6VLb3ofxXt8_6tdBvomo4bLF1gQ&oe=629130B9&_nc_sid=55e238', 'comment_reactors': [], 'comment_reactions': None, 'comment_reaction_count': None}]}, {'comment_id': '4711139555598006', 'comment_url': 'https://facebook.com/4711139555598006', 'commenter_id': '701492359', 'commenter_url': 'https://facebook.com/Flaherty.Westfield?fref=nf&rc=p&refid=52&__tn__=R', 'commenter_name': 'Dave Flaherty', 'commenter_meta': None, 'comment_text': 'You can't improve what you can't measure. If "standardized test scores and outdated accountability data" are not helpful as you say above, what would WPS and the other school districts in the Commonwealth recommend as an alternative? How would they gauge performance in a way that is consistent across districts? Across the country? How should the public compare administrators,
leaders, educators? How can they measure student achievement and readiness for their next phase in life (grade advancement, college, workforce, military service, etc...)?

Schools and communities across the country are facing the same challenges. We all get it. However, some districts are clearly outperforming others. Some are struggling to reach mediocrity.', 'comment_time': datetime.datetime(2021, 10, 24, 9, 35, 56), 'comment_image': 'https://scontent.xx.fbcdn.net/m1/v/t6/An_UvxJXg9tdnLU3Y5qjPi0200MLilhzPXUgxzGjQzUMaNcmjdZA6anyrngvkdub33NZzZhd51fpCAEzNHFhko5aKRFP5fS1w_lKwYrzcNLupv27.png?ccb=10-5&oh=00_AT_KPW4BOqeotp1qkXm6VLb3ofxXt8_6tdBvomo4bLF1gQ&oe=629130B9&_nc_sid=55e238', 'comment_reactors': [], 'comment_reactions': None, 'comment_reaction_count': None, 'replies': [{'comment_id': '4711301862248442', 'comment_url': 'https://facebook.com/4711301862248442', 'commenter_id': '546866082025395', 'commenter_url': 'https://facebook.com/WestfieldMAPublicSchools/?rc=p&refid=52&__tn__=%7ERR', 'commenter_name': 'Westfield', 'commenter_meta': 'Author', 'comment_text': 'Dave Flaherty A license is required. Because there is such a teacher shortage, emergency licenses are being handed out by DESE in record numbers. In regard to accountability,
DESE has not assigned accountability to schools or districts in two years now because of the pandemic. So everyone is essentially sitting where they were in 2019.', 'comment_time': datetime.datetime(2021, 10, 24, 9, 35, 56), 'comment_image': 'https://scontent.xx.fbcdn.net/m1/v/t6/An_UvxJXg9tdnLU3Y5qjPi0200MLilhzPXUgxzGjQzUMaNcmjdZA6anyrngvkdub33NZzZhd51fpCAEzNHFhko5aKRFP5fS1w_lKwYrzcNLupv27.png?ccb=10-5&oh=00_AT_KPW4BOqeotp1qkXm6VLb3ofxXt8_6tdBvomo4bLF1gQ&oe=629130B9&_nc_sid=55e238', 'comment_reactors': [], 'comment_reactions': None, 'comment_reaction_count': None}, {'comment_id': '4711250288920266', 'comment_url': 'https://facebook.com/4711250288920266', 'commenter_id': '804188956', 'commenter_url': 'https://facebook.com/sczaporowski?fref=nf&rc=p&__tn__=R', 'commenter_name': 'Stefan Czaporowski', 'commenter_meta': None, 'comment_text': 'Dave Flaherty Thank you very much for the feedback. We are using the data that we have from both the MCAS and benchmark assessments to improve instruction and student outcomes. Every school has a data team and a student-teacher
assistance team to determine student intervention needs. In addition, DESE updated their accountability determination methods in 2017. Schools and districts should be evaluated by this new system.

The concern is that the two major factors affecting student success right now are the lack of qualified staff and mental health needs. These two factors directly affect student performance.', 'comment_time': datetime.datetime(2021, 10, 24, 9, 35, 57), 'comment_image': 'https://scontent.xx.fbcdn.net/m1/v/t6/An_UvxJXg9tdnLU3Y5qjPi0200MLilhzPXUgxzGjQzUMaNcmjdZA6anyrngvkdub33NZzZhd51fpCAEzNHFhko5aKRFP5fS1w_lKwYrzcNLupv27.png?ccb=10-5&oh=00_AT_KPW4BOqeotp1qkXm6VLb3ofxXt8_6tdBvomo4bLF1gQ&oe=629130B9&_nc_sid=55e238', 'comment_reactors': [], 'comment_reactions': None, 'comment_reaction_count': None}, {'comment_id': '4711279662250662', 'comment_url': 'https://facebook.com/4711279662250662', 'commenter_id': '701492359', 'commenter_url': 'https://facebook.com/Flaherty.Westfield?fref=nf&rc=p&__tn__=R', 'commenter_name': 'Dave Flaherty', 'commenter_meta': None, 'comment_text': 'I thought in Massachusetts it was required to be qualified in order to get a DESE license? Qualified and top-quality are also two very different things. We have our share of both in Westfield. A performance measurement system does help track and improve results. Maybe the 2017 updated system will help? Maybe not. Seems to me we’ve had several educational performance improvement programs over the last 15 years or so at the Federal and State level. All promised great things, but I‘m not sure we’ve actually seen measurably better results. Throwing a pandemic in the mix has certainly added significant new stresses and challenges for all.', 'comment_time': datetime.datetime(2021, 10, 24, 9, 35, 57), 'comment_image': 'https://scontent.xx.fbcdn.net/m1/v/t6/An_UvxJXg9tdnLU3Y5qjPi0200MLilhzPXUgxzGjQzUMaNcmjdZA6anyrngvkdub33NZzZhd51fpCAEzNHFhko5aKRFP5fS1w_lKwYrzcNLupv27.png?ccb=10-5&oh=00_AT_KPW4BOqeotp1qkXm6VLb3ofxXt8_6tdBvomo4bLF1gQ&oe=629130B9&_nc_sid=55e238', 'comment_reactors': [], 'comment_reactions': None, 'comment_reaction_count': None}]}]

text:
If you've been paying attention to the news, you've likely seen parents from around the state and the country asking school boards to address a variety of issues affecting public education. Two of those issues - Social and Emotional Learning and Critical Race Theory - were addressed directly and at length by Board President Jim Williams during our last meeting. If you would like some detailed insights on our approach to these issues, please take the time to view President Williams' comments here: https://youtu.be/fW3v_xepjo0.

YOUTUBE.COM
MCS School Board President Jim Williams addresses SEL & CRT at 9/28/21 Board Meeting

text:
From Superintendent Dr. Eugene Schmidt – Farmington Municipal Schools (FMS) is aware of the conversations at the federal, state and local level about Critical Race Theory (CRT). FMS does not provide instruction on Critical Race Theory and the School Board does not intend to bring forth any action to introduce CRT to our schools.

Read more: https://bit.ly/3DVhvKd

text:
Check out our Weekly Parent Update from Mr. Elliott
#leveluprebelup #PrideandExcellence

Good afternoon Rebels,
This is your proud Superintendent, Mr. Elliott, with your weekly update for Friday September 3, 2021.
Congratulations:
Congratulations the Stark County Board of Education who has been selected for the 2021 IASB School Governance Recognition for Excellence in School Board Leadership. The SC Board of Education will be honored later this fall. We want to thank the current and former board leadership for the great accomplishment: Ann Orwig, Bruce West, Brian Rewerts, Dave Steward, Beth Rumbold, Matthew Nagode, Emily Holman and Erin Price.
Sex Education and Critical Race Theory Legislation:
In regards to recent Illinois Legislation for Sex Education Curriculum and political topic of the Critical Race theory, here is an update in regards to Stark County:
1) New Sex Education: Per the new legislation and ROE, the sex education changes are ONLY for school boards who want to opt into the new expanded curriculum. A school board may choose to stay with our current sex education curriculum. Currently, Stark County Board of Education will not pursue any sex education curriculum changes.
2). The Critical Race Theory is a post graduate level study, not mandated curriculum, that was created at Harvard University. With that stated, the most recent Illinois social studies/history legislation is an “opts school boards can create new courses that focus on Black Lives Matter, Black History, etc. The only requirement curriculum change is to ensure a level Asian American History is taught, which is already in our textbooks/curriculum.
Parking:
With feedback from the community, we will continue the tradition of allowing parking at home football games at Gary Johnson field. We ask that you enter by 6:30 pm to avoid traffic inside the gates for safety reasons and also allow all foot traffic to exit the stadium before moving your vehicles. Due to a water line repair, all spectators for tonight’s game will enter and pay at the north or south gate. The new middle gate is currently closed.
COVID-19 Protocols and On-Site Testing:
A reminder to view our COVID-19 protocols for contact tracing and quarantine/isolation posted on our website @stark100. We remind you that options 2-4 are only available if you follow the health departments guidelines of daily check-ins via text or app once placed into COVID isolation or healthy Quarantine. If these daily contacts with the Health Department are not made the time out of school will be 14 days.
We are also offering on-site Binax-NOW rapid testing to staff and students in our nurses’ offices if you have a parent consent form on file and opt into Option 4, “Test to Stay” Protocols. Please contact your school for any questions.
https://drive.google.com/file/d/11-dWmZiHll-pgfjFpHjZARrI7E7VR67n/view?usp=sharing
SC Sportsmanship:
As we enter the new year and full athletics seasons, we remind you that here at Stark County we take great pride in representing our schools and communities with good sportsmanship. Please avoid yelling or criticizing players, coaches, officials or programs during games and practices. Also, please use social media to promote our programs in a positive way. The world is filled with negativity, so let’s take the high road and remain positive Stark County.
Live Broadcasts Sponsorships and Reserved Football Seating Available:
With the pandemic continuing to affect our lives, Stark County will again have live broadcasts of varsity volleyball, football and boys/girls basketball with announcers presenting football and basketball. In order to fund this initiative, we are seeking game sponsors. If your family or business is interested, please check out the criteria for Gold, Silver and Bronze sponsorships posted today on our Facebook and contact me at belliott@stark100.com or 309-695-6123 to participate in sponsorships.
We also have our reserved “Red Chair” seating available for home football games. There are still Red Football seats available for purchase at the Gary Johnson Football Field in Wyoming. Cost is $50 each, if interested please contact the HS office.
COVID-19 Health Update for August 29 – September 3:
• 1 COVID-19 Positive Student Cases (SCES)
• 1 Student close contact (SCES, entered into “Test to Stay” protocol)
• 0 Staff Cases or Quarantines
Principal’s Weekly Updates:
A reminder to listen and read your weekly principal updates from Mrs. Bibb and Ms. McGann to prepare you and your children for the week ahead including the SCJSH Open House on Thursday and the full 2021 Homecoming week including event night, bonfire, parade, dance and more!
As always, thank you for being the Pride and Excellence of Stark County. Bookshakalaka, take the on a rare….Sunday!!!
#LevelUpRebelUp
-Mr. Elliott

DRIVE.GOOGLE.COM
Parent COVID Consent To Testing SC100 Draft.pdf

text:
More than 70 parents and community members joined Klamath County School District Superintendent Glen Szymoniak tonight (Sept. 2) on the lawn of Mazama High School for a discussion about schools and state mandates. The forum was followed by a question and answer session.

As the event began, football players gathered on nearby Viking Field, warming up for an evening game.

Klamath County Sheriff Chris Kaber was among the first to address the crowd, explaining he supported their right to peaceably protest but asking that those who wish to do so not disrupt the first day of school for students.

Some parents wanted the school district to defy the state mask mandate, risking educators’ certifications as well as fines and loss of liability insurance. But others said it was an unacceptable risk to ask of teachers and administrators. (The state is requiring the wearing of masks inside all K-12 school buildings.)

Janah Moorer, who will be a senior at Mazama when school starts next week, told the crowd she is ready to be back in the classroom fulltime after a year of distance learning and hybrid schedules.

“I’m not a fan of masks, but I’m willing to make that sacrifice,” she said.

For nearly 40 minutes, community members had the floor, asking questions about state mandates and how school will look for students this fall.

Superintendent Glen Szymoniak then answered as many questions as time allowed. He also explained how the district will continue to advocate for local control, which would allow leaders to work with Klamath County Public Health to determine how best to handle COVID-19.

Questions ranged from staffing, mask mandates and vaccination requirements for school staff to critical race theory (CRT is not part of the district’s curriculum). The school district is compiling the questions and answers and will post them on our website at www.kcsd.k12.or.us.

As the meeting ended, the football game started and fans could be heard cheering. Szymoniak thanked parents and community members for taking the time to attend the town hall before joining Mazama Principal Jennifer Hawkins and heading to Viking Field to watch the students play.

“We all care about our children and want our schools open,” he said. “I will always be accountable to you and listen to you. Now whether I can do everything you want? I can’t make that promise, but I can promise you that I’m going to provide you with a respectful environment so you can get your questions answered.”
post_text:
More than 70 parents and community members joined Klamath County School District Superintendent Glen Szymoniak tonight (Sept. 2) on the lawn of Mazama High School for a discussion about schools and state mandates. The forum was followed by a question and answer session.

As the event began, football players gathered on nearby Viking Field, warming up for an evening game.

Klamath County Sheriff Chris Kaber was among the first to address the crowd, explaining he supported their right to peaceably protest but asking that those who wish to do so not disrupt the first day of school for students.

Some parents wanted the school district to defy the state mask mandate, risking educators’ certifications as well as fines and loss of liability insurance. But others said it was an unacceptable risk to ask of teachers and administrators. (The state is requiring the wearing of masks inside all K-12 school buildings.)

Janah Moorer, who will be a senior at Mazama when school starts next week, told the crowd she is ready to be back in the classroom fulltime after a year of distance learning and hybrid schedules.

“I’m not a fan of masks, but I’m willing to make that sacrifice,” she said.

For nearly 40 minutes, community members had the floor, asking questions about state mandates and how school will look for students this fall.

Superintendent Glen Szymoniak then answered as many questions as time allowed. He also explained how the district will continue to advocate for local control, which would allow leaders to work with Klamath County Public Health to determine how best to handle COVID-19.

Questions ranged from staffing, mask mandates and vaccination requirements for school staff to critical race theory (CRT is not part of the district’s curriculum). The school district is compiling the questions and answers and will post them on our website at www.kcsd.k12.or.us.

As the meeting ended, the football game started and fans could be heard cheering. Szymoniak thanked parents and community members for taking the time to attend the town hall before joining Mazama Principal Jennifer Hawkins and heading to Viking Field to watch the students play.

“We all care about our children and want our schools open,” he said. “I will always be accountable to you and listen to you. Now whether I can do everything you want? I can’t make that promise, but I can promise you that I’m going to provide you with a respectful environment so you can get your questions answered.”

In this video, CCSD Superintendent of Schools George Welsh and Superintendent Designee Adam Hartman share a conversation about Critical Race Theory and its impact on the Cañon City School District.

By watching, you will again in your understanding of what Critical Race Theory is, whether CCSD teaches it, and what CCSD is doing to support high-quality education for students steeped in fairness and kindness.

text:
Join Us for Community Forums on Curriculum Updates

Assistant Superintendent for Instruction Melanie Ward will be sharing the NYSED Culturally Responsive-Sustaining Framework and recent updates to Pittsford’s K-12 English/language arts and social studies curriculum at the following events:

Secondary Curriculum Review for Grades 6-12
TOMORROW, August 26, 6:30-7:30pm at Calkins Road Middle School, commons

Culturally Responsive-Sustaining Education is not the same as Critical Race Theory

Culturally Responsive-Sustaining Education is a research-based, NYSED required approach to how we interact in the classroom, in an attempt to connect with each student and help create an environment where everyone reaches their full potential.

Critical Race Theory is a term that is being used a lot recently, but is not being taught in our schools. Critical Race Theory is about challenging historical approaches to the teaching of topics connected to race. It is a social and legal construct, typically discussed in university settings.

Join us to learn more about the NYSED framework and PCSD curriculum updates by registering here: https://www.pittsfordschools.org/Page/25783.

ASL interpretation services will be provided during the events. The forums will be recorded and posted on the PCSD YouTube page.

Join us to learn more about the NYSED framework and PCSD curriculum updates by registering here: https://www.pittsfordschools.org/Page/25783.

ASL interpretation services will be provided during the events. The forums will be recorded and posted on the PCSD YouTube page.

text:
The District 49 Board of Education voted 3-2 on Thursday approving a revised version of a resolution addressing Critical Race Theory and its inclusion in D49 classrooms.
The resolution declares the district’s official opposition to principles of CRT.

Highlights of the resolution include the following:

D49 will not use principles of Critical Race Theory (as described below) as a curriculum for classroom instruction. With this statement, D49 reiterates that:

~ Neither schools, nor instructors, shall assign individuals or groups of students to participate in class or complete assignments based on their racial identity.
~ Schools shall not engage in racial bias or stereotyping.

District leaders and staff shall not promote the following principles associated with Critical Race
Theory in D49’s classroom curricula:

~ Race Essentialism: The assertion that race is the most important identity
~ Collectivism: The assertion that group identity is more important than individual identity
~ Accusatory characterization of individuals as oppressor or oppressed according to their race

The resolution affirms D49’s commitment and expectation that teachers will rely on the Colorado Academic Standards as the authoritative source for the content of instruction on U.S. history and other social sciences.

Video from the BOE meeting
https://youtu.be/tIJCi2hKKr0?t=4560
1:16:00 Open Forum Public Remarks
1:48:20 BOE Remarks
2:02:30 D49 Chief Officer Remarks
2:13:48 BOE President Remarks
2:17:50 BOE Vote

PDF Version of the Resolution
https://go.boarddocs.com/co/d49/Board.nsf/files/C5JNCP5F43D6/$file/CRT%20Resolution%20Simplified%20dtd%202021-0802%20v2.pdf

YOUTUBE.COM
BOE Meetings Live Stream Aug. 12, 2021

text:
To discourage rumors and correct misunderstandings, EASD has published more detailed information on Monday evening's Leader In Me Equity In Education Parent/Guardian Night. Parents and guardians are critical stakeholders in our education system. As such, the Equity In Education program is for the adults connected to our students and is designed to equip you with information to help build student leadership capacity. The Leader In Me Equity In Education program is neither a curriculum for students nor is it Critical Race Theory. For clarification purposes, Critical Race Theory IS NOT taught in our schools K-12. Instead, the purpose of the Equity in Education program is to ensure our schools feel safe and are conducive to learning for every student. Read more at ⬇️
https://tinyurl.com/442u9nhu

text:
A student reinstatement hearing of the Board of Education, Gwinn Area Community Schools, will be held on Monday, August 16, 2021 in the Gwinn Middle/High School Library.

Hearing called to order: 6:00 P.M.

The agenda for the hearing is as follows:
1) Call to Order
2) Approval of Agenda
3) Public Comment
4) Student Reinstatement Hearing
a) Student D
5) Public Comment
6) Board Member Comments
7) Adjourn

The regular meeting of the Board of Education, Gwinn Area Community Schools, will be held on Monday, August 16, 2021 in the Gwinn Middle/High School Library.

Meeting called to order: 6:30 P.M.

1. Call to Order
2. Pledge of Allegiance
3. Approval of Minutes
4. Approval of Agenda
5. Public Comment
6. Financial Report
a. Approval of Monthly Check Register
b. Financial Report
7. Information
a. Sinking Fund Update
b. Strategic Plan Update
c. Critical Race Theory
d. Department Updates
8. Superintendent’s Report
a. Board Report
b. Correspondence
10. Old Business – Action
a. 5th grade HIV/AIDS video
11. New Business – Action
a. Board Appointments
b. Approve Bakery & Dairy Bids
c. Approve Propane Bids
d. Student Handbook Changes
i. Gwinn Elementary Schools
ii. Gwinn Middle/High School
e. Approve list of GACS Classes offered for Credit/State Aid
i. Elementary
ii. Middle School
iii. High School (including all online courses)
f. School Inspection Contract
g. Increase Breakfast & Lunch prices at GMS/GHS
h. JUUL Resolution
i. Personnel
1. Resignations
i. Heather Strohm – bus driver, Gwinn Bus Garage/custodian, KI Sawyer Elementary School – effective date of resignation – July 29, 2021
ii. Lauren Hemmila – special education teacher, Gilbert Elementary School, effective date of resignation – July 31, 2021
2. Employment
i. Olivia Johnson – 1st grade teacher, KI Sawyer Elementary School, effective date of employment – 1st day of the 2021-22 contract year
ii. Jason Stansky – JV football coach, Gwinn Middle/High School, effective date of hire – 1st day of the fall 2021 season
i. Gifts/Donations
1. Donor’s Choose – “Creating an Inclusive Classroom Library” (valued at $209); Building a Classroom Library: Full STEAM Ahead” (valued at $327); “Bookshelf: A Treasure Chest for a Curious Mind (valued at $179) and “Graphic Novels” (valued at $288) donated to Mr. Rice’s classroom at Gwinn Middle/High School
2. Potlach – woodchips donated for the Gilbert and KI Sawyer Elementary School playgrounds
12. Public Comment
13. Board Member Comments
14. Adjourn

text:
From HCSD Communications: SETTING THE RECORD STRAIGHT

Last evening, several members of the public attended the School Board meeting and requested time to address the Board and Superintendent on the topic of Critical Race Theory. While NO schools in the Hernando School District teach Critical Race Theory, misinformation and unfounded claims on the topic continue to create concern.

We encourage parents and members of the community to watch this clip of Superintendent Stratton addressing the comments made during the Public Comment portion of the meeting. https://youtu.be/J2CaQXSpOe0

Thank you.

From HCSD Communications: SETTING THE RECORD STRAIGHT

Last evening, several members of the public attended the School Board meeting and requested time to address the Board and Superintendent on the topic of Critical Race Theory. While NO schools in the Hernando School District teach Critical Race Theory, misinformation and unfounded claims on the topic continue to create concern.

We encourage parents and members of the community to watch this clip of Superintendent Stratton addressing the comments made during the Public Comment portion of the meeting. https://youtu.be/J2CaQXSpOe0

Thank you.

text:
Join Us for Community Forums on Curriculum Updates

Assistant Superintendent for Instruction Melanie Ward will be sharing the NYSED Culturally Responsive-Sustaining Framework and recent updates to Pittsford’s K-12 English/language arts and social studies curriculum at the following events:

Elementary Curriculum Review for Grades K-5
Tuesday, August 24, 6:30-7:30pm at Calkins Road Middle School, commons

Secondary Curriculum Review for Grades 6-12
Thursday, August 26, 6:30-7:30pm at Calkins Road Middle School, commons

Culturally Responsive-Sustaining Education is not the same as Critical Race Theory

Culturally Responsive-Sustaining Education is a research-based, NYSED required approach to how we interact in the classroom, in an attempt to connect with each student and help create an environment where everyone reaches their full potential.

Critical Race Theory is a term that is being used a lot recently, but is not being taught in our schools. Critical Race Theory is about challenging historical approaches to the teaching of topics connected to race. It is a social and legal construct, typically discussed in university settings.

Join us to learn more about the NYSED framework and PCSD curriculum updates by registering here: https://www.pittsfordschools.org/Page/25783

PITTSFORDSCHOOLS.ORG
Curriculum & Instruction / Parent Forums on Curriculum Updates

text:
NORTH LAMAR ISD STATEMENT
REGARDING CRITICAL RACE THEORY

Dated: August 10, 2021

Considering HB 3979 passed in the recent Texas legislative session, people across the state, including the North Lamar ISD community, are asking questions about critical race theory (CRT) and whether the theory is taught in public schools. CRT is not taught at North Lamar ISD.

CRT is not a part of the social studies curriculum in Texas. The state’s social studies curriculum can be found at the following link: Texas Essential Knowledge and Skills (TEKS) https://tea.texas.gov/academics/curriculum-standards/teks/texas-essential-knowledge-and-skills . While North Lamar ISD serves a diverse community and values the thoughts, beliefs, perspectives, and experiences of all our students and staff, the curriculum for all school districts must be adopted by the Texas State Board of Education. North Lamar ISD’s curriculum follows the TEKS and CRT is not included in the District’s curriculum.

Kelli Stewart, Superintendent
North Lamar Independent School District

TEA.TEXAS.GOV
Texas Essential Knowledge and Skills | Texas Education Agency

text:
Here is some information that might clear up what is happening at the School Board Meeting tonight.

Dr. Krage is sharing with the Board that our school district is not teaching the Critical Race Theory curriculum, however we do include the teaching of tolerance and equal access in our classrooms and they are part of the CO State Social Studies standards.
post_text:
Here is some information that might clear up what is happening at the School Board Meeting tonight.

Dr. Krage is sharing with the Board that our school district is not teaching the Critical Race Theory curriculum, however we do include the teaching of tolerance and equal access in our classrooms and they are part of the CO State Social Studies standards.

text:
Dear Rocket Nation,

As we get closer to our September 7th start date for the 2021-2022 school year, I would like to address a couple of HOT TOPIC issues with you!

The first one deals with Masks. Conotton Valley School will not be mandating the wearing of masks. However, we will certainly welcome any student or staff to wear one if they choose. We will maintain our heightened sanitization and hand-washing protocols.

Additionally, the Board of Education has purchased air purifiers for every classroom. We will continue to collaborate with the Carroll County Health Department to monitor any outbreaks.

Let me assure you that your child’s safety is a priority, and we will do everything possible to provide a clean and safe atmosphere for the educational process to take place. Unless we are required to alter this plan by law, or the Ohio Department of Education, this will be our approach.

The second topic is The Critical Race Theory. There is growing debate and controversy centering around the teaching of Critical Race Theory in America’s public schools. Conotton Valley Union Local School District is for ALL students and families, period. As we enter our sixth year of “Leader in Me,” the staff embeds the 7 habits and our Core Values of Honesty, Self-Discipline, Equity, Passion, Growth Mindset, Collaboration, Perseverance, and Responsibility into our daily instruction.

We teach Ohio’s learning standards for each grade level and content area. We carefully select curriculum materials and resources to support learning and cause students to process information, engage in thoughtful discussion/debate and think critically for themselves. We empower teachers to utilize evidence-based instructional strategies to create optimum learning opportunities for all students.

We create a welcoming, safe, and positive environment for all students, staff, and guests. We treat students and each other with dignity, respect, and kindness. CRT is not part of our curriculum and will not be instructed. Conotton Valley Union Local School District is always prepared for students to question and discuss current events openly and thoughtfully.

“We are in control of our mission.”
Todd Herman, Superintendent

text: The North Central Local Schools has an important curriculum update about Critical Race Theory as listed in this letter from the district.
post_text: The North Central Local Schools has an important curriculum update about Critical Race Theory as listed in this letter from the district.

text:
The Carteret County Public School System’s Board of Education met at 6:00 p.m. at Croatan High School in Newport, N.C. to consider revisions to Carteret County Board of Education Policy 7720 - Employee Political Activities, for first review. In addition, the Board of Education also considered operational protocols based on revisions to the North Carolina Department of Health and Human Services (NCDHHS) StrongSchoolsNC Public Health Toolkit for kindergarten through 12th grade.

The revision of Policy 7720 - Employee Political Activities was considered for a first read by the Board of Education members. The policy revision included the following statement:

This policy should not be construed as prohibiting the impartial study and discussion of political or other controversial issues in the classroom setting, including the dissemination of factual information about serious problems the school system or the community may be facing because of political actions, where such teaching or information reasonably relates to the standards of the course. Both sides of the political issue shall be presented, supported by primary or balanced secondary sources so that students are provided an opportunity to be well informed and to be able to make their own decisions regarding political or other controversial issues. Further, this policy shall ensure that social theories of any kind (i.e. Holocaust Denial Theory, 9/11 Theory, Critical Race Theory) are not presented to students unless approved by the Carteret County Board of Education. It is the responsibility of the Board to ensure that curricular standards are taught using well documented, factual resources and not opinion or conjecture.

The Carteret County Public School System does not teach Critical Race Theory, nor are there any plans to do so in the future.

The Carteret County Board of Education promotes respect for all persons and encourages school system personnel to incorporate this foundational concept in all instructional activities. Students should be encouraged to think critically, freely, and with a respect for differences of opinion. The Board rejects any curriculum, instructional activity, or instructional resource that devalues any person. The school system’s frequent expression of “#CarteretStrong” is predicated upon the belief that we are “#StrongerTogether.”

Superintendent Dr. Rob Jackson gave a detailed PowerPoint presentation on NCDHHS StrongSchoolsNC Public Health Toolkit for kindergarten through 12th grade, which included updates on toolkit revisions, educational experience for students, health and wellness protocols, transportation, child nutrition, cloth face coverings, and quarantine guidelines. Dr. Jackson met with the Health Director and other health officials from the Carteret County Health Department prior to the meeting to ensure the information being presented was accurate and up-to-date.

The StrongSchoolsNC Public Health Toolkit states, “If a school does not require individuals who are not fully vaccinated to wear a mask, they should ensure a layered mitigation strategy, including physical distancing, ventilation, hand hygiene, adequate access to diagnostic and screening testing, and closely monitor for increases in COVID-19 cases.”

Board members reiterated the priority placed on the health and safety of students and staff and the importance of students attending school face-to-face.

After Dr. Jackson's presentation and discussion by Board members, a unanimous decision was made by the Carteret County Board of Education to make masks optional in Carteret County Public Schools. Students and staff members will not be required to wear masks during the 2021-2022 school year, however, mask-wearing is optional for students and staff.

text:
To: All Republic County USD 109 Patrons
Date: August 2, 2021
Re: Response to Critical Race Theory

The subject of critical race theory has been dominating the media and social media headlines lately. Just as we teach our students to be judicious consumers of information, we encourage all patrons to educate themselves on what critical race theory (CRT) truly is and what it is not.

Critical race theory is not part of the Kansas State Department of Education, nor Republic County USD 109’s academic standards that we teach in our classrooms. Our curriculum is aligned with the Kansas State Department of Education’s academic standards that can be found at www.ksde.org.

Republic County USD 109 is a learning community dedicated to and continues to ensure educational practices and excellence so that all students achieve at high levels and graduate prepared for success in college, careers and live in a rapidly changing world.

Republic County USD 109 will continue to teach the exact same academic standards as the district has been teaching in our classrooms.

Educationally,

Larry Lyder
Superintendent

text:
Colonial Heights School Board clarifies policies

COLONIAL HEIGHTS, Va. -\-\ Over the past several weeks, citizens and parents in Colonial Heights and across Virginia have expressed concern about news they are hearing at a state and national level related to public schools. As members of the Colonial Heights School Board, we want to collectively assure the citizens of Colonial Heights that our schools continue to be committed to being welcoming and safe places where all students and staff are valued and respected. We embrace equity of opportunity for all students and staff as we work hard together to advance and support student learning and be the best we can be as a community.

To be clear, Critical Race Theory is not included in the curriculum for Colonial Heights Public Schools and is not included in current state standards of learning. History and social studies must be studied honestly and accurately, but students are not judged by the color of their skin under any circumstances. We must all be accountable for our actions as individuals, correct wrongs where they exist, and work together united rather than divided for the good of our community.

Likewise, Colonial Heights Public Schools has not changed its policies regarding transgender students. We do not discriminate in our schools and will continue to work with students needing support on an individual basis and respect their privacy, in an environment that is safe and respectful of all students.

Having worked through the incredibly challenging past year of the pandemic, our schools and community are stronger than ever and there is nothing we cannot face working together. We value all our students and families and look forward to having everyone back for the coming school year in September.

Colonial Heights School Board clarifies policies

COLONIAL HEIGHTS, Va. -\-\ Over the past several weeks, citizens and parents in Colonial Heights and across Virginia have expressed concern about news they are hearing at a state and national level related to public schools. As members of the Colonial Heights School Board, we want to collectively assure the citizens of Colonial Heights that our schools continue to be committed to being welcoming and safe places where all students and staff are valued and respected. We embrace equity of opportunity for all students and staff as we work hard together to advance and support student learning and be the best we can be as a community.

To be clear, Critical Race Theory is not included in the curriculum for Colonial Heights Public Schools and is not included in current state standards of learning. History and social studies must be studied honestly and accurately, but students are not judged by the color of their skin under any circumstances. We must all be accountable for our actions as individuals, correct wrongs where they exist, and work together united rather than divided for the good of our community.

Likewise, Colonial Heights Public Schools has not changed its policies regarding transgender students. We do not discriminate in our schools and will continue to work with students needing support on an individual basis and respect their privacy, in an environment that is safe and respectful of all students.

Having worked through the incredibly challenging past year of the pandemic, our schools and community are stronger than ever and there is nothing we cannot face working together. We value all our students and families and look forward to having everyone back for the coming school year in September.

text:
To our Springboro Families,

Springboro Schools would like to address the recent questions and concerns that have been shared by parents and community members regarding Critical Race Theory (CRT) and if CRT is being considered for this district’s curriculum. Additionally, we would like to clarify the purpose of the Superintendent’s Diversity & Inclusion (D&I) Committee.

Springboro Schools has not and will not support or implement CRT into our curriculum at any grade level. Additionally, our curriculum will not include the following topics that are sometimes associated with CRT:

• Teaching from a perspective that the United States and/or its legal system is systematically racist and designed to create and maintain inequalities between genders, ethnicities, different religious heritages, or races
• Teaching that socialism and communism are morally superior to democracy, capitalism, and a free market economy
• That any gender, ethnicity, religious heritage, or race should feel superior or inferior
• That one should feel guilt or shame due to their ethnicity, religious heritage, race, or gender

Springboro Schools follows the Ohio Department of Education’s (ODE) Learning Standards. Those standards for social studies were reviewed and adopted in 2018, and do not include CRT. As standards are updated and released, the Superintendent will make recommendations to the Board of Education on whether or not to adopt them. Springboro Schools would not recommend the support of the aforementioned curriculum items that are outlined above. To view ODE’s current standards for social studies, as well as all other subject areas, please visit - http://education.ohio.gov/Topics/Learning-in-Ohio/OLS-Graphic-Sections/Learning-Standards.

The D&I Committee’s focus is on improving the learning environment within Springboro Schools, in order to ensure that every student, regardless of ethnicity, religious heritage, gender, or race, feels welcome, safe, and ready to learn. The D&I Committee is not responsible for the district’s curriculum, nor does it have the authority to implement any changes to it; only the Superintendent and the Board of Education hold that authority. Report-outs and recommendations from the D&I Committee will continue to be public and are still subject to approval by the Superintendent and Board of Education. This is consistent with all other Superintendent committees.

Springboro Schools is committed to maintaining our excellent curriculum, which is the educational foundation of countless Springboro graduates who have gone on to enjoy success in numerous pursuits such as college, vocational school, military service, and skilled trades. We will also strive to continuously improve our environment and student experience so that every student is able to feel welcome and safe.

Thank you,

Larry Hook, Superintendent Springboro Schools

THIS IS CRT and what your kids would actually learn...
.
Battle of Bamber Bridge
Jun 24, 1943 – Jun 25, 1943
On this day in 1943 black American soldiers faced off with white American Military police during World War II on British soil. Yes you read correctly black American soldiers had to fight their own white American soldiers, while in England, where they were fighting for the world.
Why? Because the English town of Bamber Bridge in Lancashire was not segregated so they treated the black soldiers like all other races, aka blacks were free to eat, drink anywhere, BUT back in America segregation of blacks and whites still existed. So essentially the American army went to someone else’s country and demanded they adopted America’s racist practices
So when the American Military police found out that their own black American soldiers were drinking at the same pubs as white people they went in to arrest them. The people in the town got mad about the treatment of the black soldiers and decided to then turn their pubs into “BLACKS ONLY DRINKING PUBS” the very opposite of what was taking place in America with their WHITES ONLY businesses.
Of course this pissed off the American military so guns went blazing, and when word spread back at camp that black soldiers had been shot, scores of men formed a crowd, some carrying rifles and by midnight more American military police arrived with a machine gun-equipped vehicle, so the black soldiers had no choice but to get rifles from British stores while others barricaded themselves back on base, so now it was American white soldiers versus American black soldiers. This lead to the death of one solider, injury of 7, and 32 convictions.
Back in America the battle was hushed up because they didn’t want the country to find out that they were fighting their own soldiers which would anger the black population and weaken the morale in the country.
You may read about the ill treatment of black American soldiers by their own army in the book FORGOTTEN.', 'comment_time': datetime.datetime(2021, 7, 24, 10, 20, 30), 'comment_image': 'https://scontent.xx.fbcdn.net/m1/v/t6/An_UvxJXg9tdnLU3Y5qjPi0200MLilhzPXUgxzGjQzUMaNcmjdZA6anyrngvkdub33NZzZhd51fpCAEzNHFhko5aKRFP5fS1w_lKwYrzcNLupv27.png?ccb=10-5&oh=00_AT_KPW4BOqeotp1qkXm6VLb3ofxXt8_6tdBvomo4bLF1gQ&oe=629130B9&_nc_sid=55e238', 'comment_reactors': [], 'comment_reactions': None, 'comment_reaction_count': None, 'replies': []}, {'comment_id': '5687670511303764', 'comment_url': 'https://facebook.com/5687670511303764', 'commenter_id': '39504700', 'commenter_url': 'https://facebook.com/johnathon.gallienne?fref=nf&rc=p&refid=52&__tn__=R', 'commenter_name': 'Johnathon Gallienne', 'commenter_meta': None, 'comment_text': 'Will students still be able to learn about Springboro's role in the Underground Railroad as long as teachers refer to slavery as "unpleasantness

text:
Shout out to these brave, articulate students for sharing their perspectives on the new Black History and Black Literature courses. Love seeing our students stay informed and share their thoughts on District news! https://bit.ly/3BwxNaZ

KSDK.COM
Francis Howell schools will offer Black history, literature courses

rents-n1463953', 'comment_time': datetime.datetime(2021, 7, 24, 10, 21, 13), 'comment_image': 'https://pjmedia.com/news-and-politics/rick-moran/2021/07/22/missouri-teachers-plotted-with-crt-advocate-to-hide-radical-teaching-from-parents-n1463953?fbclid=IwAR1g7c9AdvFSPikwZuH2HrHhvDh4gJQ9pRQXD5EucHZZOy7KCt7B6utTUx8', 'comment_reactors': [], 'comment_reactions': None, 'comment_reaction_count': None, 'replies': []}, {'comment_id': '3989092781220148', 'comment_url': 'https://facebook.com/3989092781220148', 'commenter_id': '100025268136399', 'commenter_url': 'https://facebook.com/hollie.m7?fref=nf&rc=p&refid=52&__tn__=R', 'commenter_name': 'Hollie Martin', 'commenter_meta': None, 'comment_text': 'Let’s be aware of one crucial difference:
Marxism is not the same as Communism.

Marxism is the study of how the aristocracy strives to preserve their place in society. The bourgeoise want to be the aristocracy, so they strive to keep the proletariat in their place.

That’s a very simple summary, but it’s a social construct that we actually do see in America in different ways… for instance, the occupy wall street movement several years ago, “we are the 99%”. Did the 1%, the aristocracy of America, actually change anything? Not really. Why would they? They don’t want to surrender their position. Would you?

I grew up in this school district myself. People of color were revered and respected when I was in school. This was way back in the late 90s to 2003. I wish wish wish there were more people of color around me when I was growing up. You don’t get to know THEIR struggles. I’ve been so indoctrinated growing up, and African American studies should be an option for study or how will all of we white people surrounded by mostly white people EVER understand what we, ourselves never went through? It is a definite, undeniable part of ALL of our histories as Americans. To deny a child the option to learn about something in their own history as an American human is almost blasphemous. I’m 37 now, and I don’t ever want my little girl to grow up with simple and plain IGNORANCE about other races and make assumptions. I teach her now that we are all children of God(public school, but relevant for us, personally), all of us. I feel, as a white woman, removing these class options is similar to what I’ve only heard about, segregation and wanting to just sweep this little blip in “unnecessary” education under the rug. EMBRACE TRUTH AND END THIS SAD BATTLE. This is a good option for our children. I’m proud it’s finally here, in this CRUEL and entitled community, of which I’ve also grown up in. I’m embarrassed to see the parents my age around here now. Just vindictive. Something has got to change around here! If we’re not moving forward, I believe we’re just going to stand still.
The Long Walk Home
Hidden Figures

Watch these please. text:
When you come to EPL, check out our new Critical Race displays.
Critical Race Theory (CRT) explores the concept that racism is embedded in our laws and legal institutions, (according to Harvard Law Today’s Oct. 6, 2011).
With CRT entering the mainstream in recent months, now, you can check out some of these books or movies which can help explain the concept.

text:
**UPDATE**
The Daily Local's editor has revised the story to remove the reporter's personal commentary, denoted that the first speaker has never attended DASD, and corrected the inaccurate information regarding the board vote. The Daily Local has planned a follow-up article and in-person coverage at future board meetings to help present a more accurate and balanced report of the evening.

***

The Daily Local News published an article yesterday that inaccurately portrayed last week’s board meeting as well as the diversity, equity and inclusion (DEI) work happening in DASD. The Daily Local has revised the article to correct the inaccuracies.

To clarify any misconceptions, DASD is not teaching Critical Race Theory (CRT) and there are no plans to do so in the future. The DEI director’s role is not to create, design or revise instructional curriculum (such as critical race theory). The Pennsylvania Department of Education is clear with districts in terms of the curricular standards that we are required to teach, and DASD adheres to them.

DASD IS supporting diversity, equity and inclusion by promoting kindness, civility, understanding of people and acceptance of others’ lived experiences and backgrounds.

The cultural diversity of our student population has more than doubled in the past 10 years. In DASD, there are nearly 2,200 students receiving special education services, nearly 300 receiving gifted education services and more than 300 receiving accommodations through a section 504 service agreement. According to the Williams Institute, 4.1% of Pennsylvania’s adult population identifies at LGBT. It is our responsibility to acknowledge and respect our differences, and to provide a learning environment where all students feel safe, understood and valued. We must support all staff and students, regardless of gender, race, color, creed, sexual orientation or ability.

Schools that are inclusive and foster the whole child are better able to meet the wellness and academic needs of all students. DEI work creates a culture of kindness, respect, compassion and grace. School-wide strategies that align wellness, inclusion, diversity and equity empower all students to meet their individual and unique goals.

Some of the current curriculum is inappropriate for the aged children it is targeting. For example: the Black History Month curriculum for First Grade students is too detailed and in-depth. First grade students should not be exposed to the content on that level. In our home we do not teach our children to see color as a difference. Our son was highly upset that a little girl and her mother would have had things thrown at them and received threats of violence because she went to school. We had to open up conversations with our 7 year old first grader who was not ready for that content. Yes, the topics and historical achievements need to be introduced, however they do not need to include the description of violence at this age level. Why not teach the celebration of the historical achievement and the bravery of those involved? The children’s takeaway is the violence and that people are/were bad… not the bravery and accomplishment.

You aren’t teaching the First Grade children about the massacres that took place against the Native Peoples of our nation or the Trail of Tears. Likewise, the atrocities surrounding WWII, the Holocaust and the State Side Japanese Internment Camps are not taught at this age level so why include the violence surrounding Black History to these children? It is wholly inappropriate at this age level and something that the parents should be made aware of and therefore able to broach the subject at home. We do teach our children about these subjects and more as they are very important to us. That being said, we keep the content age appropriate. text:
Across the nation, the controversy continues over how racism is taught in schools, which some have called Critical Race Theory. However, that label is being applied to things that don't actually fit the legal academic theory that has roots in the 1970s.

KCRG.COM
What is Critical Race Theory, and why is there so much controversy surrounding it?

text:
There is a lot of discussion surrounding CRT, DEI and Comprehensive Sexual Ed. happening nationally and in our own community. To help keep families informed and to dispel any misinformation about these topics as it relates to our district we've created an informational website that outlines what is and isn't happening in our schools.

https://www.wenatcheeschools.org/news/1715707/critical-race-theory-d-e-i-and-sexual-health-ed-information

text:
IMPORTANT UPDATE FROM THE MISSOURI SCHOOL BOARDS ASSOCIATION:
Critical Race Theory and Educational Equity: What You Need to Know

Questions about Critical Race Theory and its use in public schools are becoming commonplace in our communities. Two common questions being asked are 1) What is Critical Race Theory? and 2) Is it being taught in our schools?

What Is Critical Race Theory?
Critical Race Theory (CRT) is a phrase that is frequently mentioned in the media and in public conversations. CRT might have a certain meaning to one person while someone else might believe it is something entirely different. But the most basic purpose of Critical Race Theory, which originated in the 1970s, was as an analytical tool for law students to examine the impact of historical and present-day racism on the legal system and public policies. Currently, CRT is primarily used by higher education in the study of law, psychology, and sociology.

Is Critical Race Theory in the Missouri Learning Standards?

The tenets of CRT are not part of social studies or any other learning standards in Missouri. The state’s social studies standards can be found on the Department of Elementary and Secondary Education’s website (Missouri Social Studies Learning Standards). It’s important to remember that all Missouri Learning Standards are approved by the State Board of Education and developed by Missouri educators, parents, and other community stakeholders selected by the President Pro Tem of the Senate, the Speaker of the House, the Governor, the Lieutenant Governor, the State Board of Education, the Commissioner of DESE, the Commissioner of Higher Education and various education associations. (Section 160.514, RSMo.)

Is Critical Race Theory the Same as Educational Equity?

No. Various media channels and members of the public sometimes use terms interchangeably when they mean two different things. The terms Critical Race Theory and educational equity are not the same. Unlike CRT, which, again, is a tool primarily used in institutions of higher education, educational equity is a K-12 term referring to federal and state policies and requirements. Specifically, the term is closely associated with “No Child Left Behind” (NCLB) legislation that was led by former President George W. Bush and signed into law in 2002. This federal law established clear requirements for school districts to not only disaggregate student achievement data by race but also to close achievements gaps where they exist.

In recent years, the terms equity work or diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI) has become commonplace in K-12 education as many districts revisit and renew their local efforts to close achievement gaps as required by the federal Every Student Succeeds Act (ESSA). When signed into law in 2015, ESSA further advanced equity in U.S. education policy by upholding protections outlined in NCLB, including calling for comprehensive state-developed plans designed to close achievement gaps, improve the quality of instruction, and increase outcomes for all students.

The state's accreditation system, MSIP (the Missouri School Improvement Program), includes provisions to address educational equity in Missouri’s schools. These rules were reviewed by Missouri’s Joint Committee on Administrative Rules, which is a 10-member legislative committee made up of six Republicans and four Democrats from the Missouri House and Senate. Further, the Secretary of State received comments from the public on the proposed rules and the State Board of Education considered the comments prior to final approval.
Is Critical Race Theory the Same as Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion (DEI)?
No. The focus of DEI is to ensure all students have the opportunity to receive a quality education and are provided the resources they need in order to allow for their success.

We hope you find this information helpful as questions arise about this topic.

www.mosba.org | 800.221.6722 | info@mosba.org | 2100 I-70 Drive Southwest Columbia, MO 65203

MOSBA.ORG

text:
KIPP Indy Public Schools Science teacher, Ronak Shah, emphasizes how important it is to answer his students’ questions truthfully and completely, always. So Ronak knew when his students raised many questions about the cicadas that seemed to be missing from their neighborhood, teaching them about the intersection of systemic racism and environmental inequity in Indianapolis was the rightful answer.

In this piece he wrote for Chalkbeat Indiana, Ronak unravels the long history of segregation in Indianapolis and the many lasting effects of this that are still present today.

https://in.chalkbeat.org/2021/6/28/22550964/cicadas-environmental-racism-indianapolis-critical-race-theory-crt

IN.CHALKBEAT.ORG
When students ask why they haven’t seen cicadas, we need to talk about environmental racism

Why most of my classes were majority white and from middle-to-high income households. How and why on a systemic level other school districts in Pennsylvania look different and why their experiences are different. Why all but one of my teachers from kindergarten through senior year were white. Why black history was taught on a surface level only one month out of the year. We would learn about historic events in civil rights but we would not use those as a context to discuss the modern day. Rather, the messaging was mostly “and that fixed things!” Critical Race Theory only sounds scary if you’re afraid to learn that the game you’re playing is rigged in favor of your complexion and you might need to live with some discomfort in order to make the changes that ensure diversity, equity, and inclusion. I’m disappointed that 10 years after I graduated the district is still afraid to fully embrace honest and truthful education. It has taken that amount of time for me to unlearn even a fraction of what I was led to believe about race in America and around the world. text:
Conservatives,
Before you complain about Critical Race Theory being taught in heavily liberal educational institutions, did you forgo the bigger house, the nicer car, and the once-in-a-lifetime vacations to sacrifice your present for our children's future?

If you weren't willing to become a professional educator and invest in the lives of our Nation's children, then shut up and deal with your choices. Want significant change in the educational system? Jump in and become the teachers you hope your grandchildren will be inspired to follow.

Too late in life to make the jump? Financially support the programs that focus on conservative values and standardized curriculum. For $100 a month you can help a child learn how to discover the Truth, respect our nation, and support our law enforcement personnel. www.sskids.org
